GOP 2016-JINDAL 
Jindal: US needs revival, not gun control 
DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) — Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal says mass shootings show the need for "a spiritual revival in this country." 
The Republican presidential candidate told ABC's "This Week" that the U.S. doesn't need new gun control laws that would disarm law-abiding citizens. He said what America really needs is "a renaissance of decency." 
Jindal cited what he called the "moral decay" and lack of respect for life reflected in violent movies, TV shows, song lyrics and video games. He added that the gunman in last week's Oregon college shootings was one of millions of young men without a father in the home to guide them. 
The Louisiana governor also called for stronger U.S. military action to defeat Islamic State militants.

CHICAGO ARCHBISHOP-GUNS 
Chicago archbishop calls for stronger gun regulations 
CHICAGO (AP) — Chicago's Roman Catholic archbishop is calling for stronger gun regulations in the wake of mass shootings around the nation and street violence in the city. 
Archbishop Blase Cupich (blayz SOO'-pich) wrote a commentary that was published in the Chicago Tribune over the weekend. 
He wrote that the Second Amendment's authors could not have anticipated the military-grade assault weapons of today. He quoted Pope Francis' recent remarks about the arms trade being motived by what Francis called "money that is drenched in blood." 
Cupich speculates that the pope's comments could apply to domestic weapons sales as well, and notes that the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops has consistently called for reasonable regulation of guns. 
MIDEAST-GOD'S FOOT SOLDIERS 
Jewish, Muslim groups raise temperature at contested shrine 
JERUSALEM (AP) — Jewish and Muslim grassroots groups, self-declared defenders of their faiths, have played a key role in rising Israeli-Palestinian tensions, stepping up activities at the Jerusalem hilltop revered by Jews as the Temple Mount and by Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary. 
Each side has accused the other of causing provocations. 
Israel pins much of the blame on a domestic fundamentalist group, the Islamic Movement, saying it whipped up Palestinian anger with claims that Israel is plotting to take over the Muslim-run site. Those claims, dismissed by Israel as incitement, reflect widespread Palestinian fears fueled by the doubling of Jewish visits to the shrine since 2010. 
Backed by senior Israeli politicians, activists have become more vocal in demanding Jewish prayer rights on the mount. Some call for the site's partition and the rebuilding of the biblical Jewish Temple that once stood there. 
TURKEY-BLAST 
Pope laments bombings in Turkey 
VATICAN CITY (AP) — Pope Francis has led followers in silent prayer for the victims of what he described as the "terrible slaughter" in the Turkish capital. 
The pope paused for 30 seconds of silent prayer for what he called "that dear country" during his traditional Angelus blessing Sunday. He told followers gathered in St. Peter's Square in the Vatican that news of the Ankara bomb attacks that killed 95 people brought "pain for the numerous dead, pain for the wounded and pain because the attackers hit helpless people who were demonstrating for peace." 
The twin explosions Saturday ripped through a crowd of activists rallying for increased democracy and an end to violence between Kurdish rebels and Turkish security forces. 
The Turkish government said Kurdish rebels or Islamic State militants were likely responsible, while mourners accused Turkey's president of fomenting violence to gain votes for the ruling party.

SECULAR SIGN-MARINES 
Marine base in Hawaii to keep 'God bless' sign 
HONOLULU (AP) — A Marine base in Hawaii is keeping its "God bless the military" sign despite pressure from an outside group. 
The sign at Marine Corps Base Hawaii on the island of Oahu reads, "God bless the military, their families and the civilians who work with them." It was erected after Sept. 11, 2001, and base commander Col. Sean Killeen says it stands as a secular sign of support without inhibiting other religions. 
The Honolulu Star-Advertiser reports that Killeen responded Friday to a complaint from the Military Religious Freedom Foundation based in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Founder Mikey Weinstein says his foundation represents 72 Marines on the base. 
Killeen said no service members have complained about the sign, but Weinstein argues that's because they fear retribution. His group wants the sign relocated to chapel grounds, taken down or accompanied by other signs bearing messages like "Goddess Bless" and "There is no god to bless ... We have each other." 
RELIGIOUS DOCTRINE-LEGISLATION 
Tenn. bill seeks to curtail teaching of 'religious doctrine' 
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) — A proposed bill would ban teaching Tennessee public school students "religious doctrine" until they're in the 10th grade. 
The proposal from Republican state Rep. Sheila Butt comes on the heels of complaints from parents in several communities as to what their children are learning in middle school about Islam. U.S. Rep Diane Black, R-Tenn., argues that the teachings border on indoctrination. 
The Tennessean reports that state education officials acknowledged that students might learn the Five Pillars of Islam or read from religious texts, but said the information is used to provide historical context about the influence Islam has had on regions of the world. 
According to the bill, if a religion is mentioned in middle school curriculum, then it is up to the state board of education to make sure "the reference does not amount to teaching any form of religious doctrine to the students." 
SAINT'S BODY 
Body of Italian saint to be displayed at Madison church 
MADISON, Wis. (AP) — The body of an 11-year-old Italian girl who was killed more than a century ago and declared a saint will be on display this week at a Wisconsin church that bears her name. 
Maria Goretti was stabbed in 1902 by a neighbor during a sexual assault. She forgave her attacker on her deathbed and said she hoped she they would be together in heaven. 
In 1950, the Roman Catholic Church declared Maria Goretti a saint. Starting Friday morning, the body of the young saint is scheduled to be available for public veneration at St. Maria Goretti Catholic Church in Madison for 22 hours. The church will remain open for people to file by her glass-sided casket. 
The Wisconsin State Journal reports that thousands are expected, with each person limited to 15 seconds in front of her casket. 
Although none of her remains will be visible, her wax-encased skeleton is largely complete, according to the Catholic Church. Touching the casket is believed to bring healing. 
ANTI-MUSLIM PROTEST PHOENIX 
Protesters gather to hold anti-Islam rally at Phoenix mosque 
PHOENIX (AP) — A campaign to stage demonstrations against Islam across the U.S. has gone largely unheeded, although about 200 protesters gathered in front of the Islamic Community Center in Phoenix on Saturday afternoon. 
KTAR radio reports that Usama Shami, president of the Phoenix mosque, said rally organizers were displaying their bigotry. 
The organizer of the Phoenix rally, John Ritzheimer, says he's not against Muslims, but against what he calls their ideology which he says leads them to attack people. He led a previous rally at the mosque in May after two of its former congregants were killed when they tried to attack a Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas. 
Saturday's rally in Phoenix appeared to be the largest in response to a nationwide call for protests against Islam in America this past weekend. 
SAUDI-HAJJ 
AP Exclusive: Prince says Saudis will stay in charge of hajj 
ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates (AP) — Saudi Prince Turki al-Faisal has rejected the idea of sharing the administration of the annual hajj pilgrimage with other Muslim nations, saying Riyadh considers it "a matter of sovereignty" and a "privilege." 
The senior member of the Saudi royal family spoke to The Associated Press on Sunday as his country faces mounting criticism in the wake of last month's disastrous crush of pilgrims outside the holy city of Mecca, which killed over 1,400 people, according to an AP count, making it the deadliest annual pilgrimage on record. 
Saudi Arabia's rival Iran, which lost the largest number of pilgrims, has accused the kingdom of mismanagement and called for an independent body to oversee the hajj. 
The royal Al Saud family, which governs Saudi Arabia and for which the country is named, derives enormous prestige and legitimacy from being the caretakers of the hajj and Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina. 
BRITAIN-WITCHCRAFT RISE 
UK police says witchcraft, exorcism cases on rise 
LONDON (AP) — Britain's Metropolitan Police have reported an increase in the number of child abuse cases that involve allegations of witchcraft and exorcism. 
Police said Sunday a specialist unit received 46 such cases in 2014, more than twice as many as the year before. 
The "Project Violet" unit says 60 incidents have been reported so far this year, continuing the upward trend. 
Detective Sergeant Terry Sharpe said the number of incidents remains "small in number" but that "there has been a significant increase." 
He said in one case a 9-year-old boy was called a "devil child" and was thrown out of his home by his parents. Another case involved a mother who believed her son was a witch and tried to bite and smother him. 
INDIA-DALAI LAMA 
The Dalai Lama says Buddhist culture most important to him 
DHARMSALA, India (AP) — The Dalai Lama says that for him, the most important thing is to preserve the Buddhist culture that has helped the Tibetan people live together, even in exile. He also said he regrets that some people use religion to harm others and said he supports teaching secular values. 
The 80-year-old Tibetan Buddhist leader made the comments Saturday at his first public meeting since returning to India last week from the U.S., where he underwent a thorough medical checkup. 
Many Tibetans fear that their culture may not endure for long and may weaken after the Dalai Lama is gone. 
Dozens of school children in traditional Tibetan costumes welcomed the Dalai Lama, and he looked cheerful as he responded to his followers' greetings. 
Beijing accuses him of seeking to separate Tibet from China. But the Dalai Lama says he simply wants a high degree of Tibetan autonomy under Chinese rule.
